heisig_chinese_memo: Many children like to represent a normal day by drawing the sun as a big circle with a smile.
heisig_story: This kanji is intended to be a pictograph of the sun. Recalling what we said in the previous frame about round forms, it is easy to detect the circle and the big smile that characterize our simplest drawings of the sun - like those yellow badges with the words, "Have a nice day!"

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The sun radical and sun kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember day as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic:
There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is ã«ã¡.
The sun is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich Nietzsche (ã«ã¡), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.
WaniKani_Reading_Info:
This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth.
Also note that there's another reading worth learning as well: ã˜ã¤. The reading can be remembered by thinking "Gee! Two readings?" Because, seriously, two readings? Too many...

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Many children like to represent a normal day by drawing the sun as a big circle with a smile.
origin_of_ch_char_book: Bronze mirror symbolizing sun. The priest who was the representative of Heaven wore this mirror at the sacrificial rites (16th-11th century BC) According to the explanation of â€œShuo Wen Jie Ziâ€ in Ancient Chinese, the character of â€œSpringâ€ (æ˜¥, chun, spring) means â€œto push.â€ Where did this meaning come from? This character describes the grasses on the top (è‰, cao=tsâ€™ao, grass), and a sprout in the middle, which is coming out on the ground , and the sun (æ—¥, ri, sun; day). The sun is pushing the sprout to pierce the ground, helping it to grow. After the cold goes away, spring comes, bringing warm sunlight and helping the new sprouts to come up to the surface of the earth. The ancient people saw this and thought, â€œthe sun helps to push the new sprouts up to the surface.â€,(å…, mian=mien, exempt)The top is a hat decorated with feathers or animal horns, and there is a person below . This represents the hat used by officials. Taking off this hat means leaving office. This character depicts an officer taking retiring frm work and stepping down from his office. It is used with a meaning of â€˜ to escape â€˜ and â€˜ to avoid â€˜. If the sunæ—¥ (ri, sun) isadded to this character, it means â€˜eveningâ€™ æ™š (wan, evening; late). That is, the sun has done his duty an is going away.
humanum_full_description_en:
The word "æ—¥" is like the sun. It was originally made of a circle, but because the circle is not easy to engrave on the oracle bones, the word may be changed to a square. " Day " in a bit to avoid the " Day " and " imports " mixed. The original meaning is the sun.

The oracle bone inscriptions are used as the original meaning, referring to the day of the celestial body, "Collection" 34163: "ã¢(æœ‰)å‡ºæ—¥", that is, the sunrise. "Collection" 11480: "Japanese have eaten (erosion)." Another Oracle " day " and " evening " relative, referring to the day, "collection" 33871: "Today the rain, evening rain." Refers to the day of rain today, but also at night rain. "Collection" 34036: "The sun is not windy (worry)", it means that there is wind in the daytime today, so don't worry. " Day " is also used as a noun of time, referring to a day, "Collection" 12314: "It has rained for five days since today." It means that it will rain for five days from today. There are also words in the inscriptions such as "Zhongri" (hours and minutes in the middle of the day), "Zhangri" (after noon), and "all days" (all days). Oracle ' Day "is also used as an offering name," collection "27463:" A Day in the Father. "A parent refers to conduct day festival.

The inscription "æ—¥" is used as the original meaning, referring to the sun, such as Mi Baishi ğ£ª•: "Yi (Luan) flag for five days." Zhang Zhengxong pointed out the pattern based on the pattern of water and land attack unearthed in Shanbiao Town, Ji County, Henan Province in 1935. There was a ship with a large flag standing on the bow, which looked like a luan body, with five circles on it, that is, like five days, similar to what Mi Bai Shizhen said. In addition, the inscription " day " is used for daytime, as opposed to " night ", [å¦¾å­]ğ§Š’ pot: "Day and night are not forgotten." " Day " is also used as a timekeeping unit. The inscription includes "today", "next day", etc. Language, such as Dan Xiaozi Ding: "Dan Xiaozitai (with) Gengyinâ€™s day destiny to make a great ding ding." Also in inscriptions , the word "æ—¥" is used in front of Ganzhi and used as the title of ancestors. One "Wen Kao Rigui". Tang Lan believed that the ancients called the ancestors according to the order of the day of sacrifice. For example, those who used the Jiari sacrifice were called the ancestors of the ancestors. Therefore, the inscription called "Wen Kao Rigui" is "Fu Gui".

"Said Wen": "Day, reality. The essence of the sun does not lose. From å›—, one. Pictogram. All the genus of the day is from the day." According to the " real " interpretation of the " day " as the sound training, it is a taboo for the Han people. The study is not necessarily the original meaning of the creation of the character. "Accounting. "Ri Zhan Yi" quoted "Chun Qiu Yuan Ming Bao": "The day is the truth, the festival also contains the one. The opening of the festival, so that things are salty, so it is called the day." That is, the " day " is called " " Day " is because it is full, has laws, and contains " one ." The opening and setting of the legislation system makes everything different, so it is called " day ."
humanum_short_description_en: The word "æ—¥" is like the shape of the sun.

day
rÃ¬
The closest star to the earth (also known as the "sun"): sun, moon and stars. Sundial (gu?) (an ancient device that used the shadow cast by the sun to measure the time). Prominence. The sun is thinning to the west (the sun is about to set, which means that aging people or rotten things are close to death).
During the day, as opposed to "night": day shift.
Day, day and night: not seen for many days. today. schedule.
One day: Anniversary.
The unit of time for calculating work, usually eight hours or six hours as a working day.
Time: Kasuga. Old days.
Every day, day by day: diary. increasingly.
Specifically refers to "Japan".

Meaning Mnemonic
The sun radical and sun kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember day as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!
Reading Mnemonic
There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is ã«ã¡.
The sun is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich Nietzsche (ã«ã¡), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.
This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth.
